body:
Thanks for merging. After asking for advice on how to go about writing tests in the original PR, I did not receive a response so decided to try to come up with something myself.

Most of the line count you're seeing here is from capturing snapshots of the generated OCaml  code under various scenarios. I tried to keep the scenarios as simple as possible however the outputs of the service client implementations are verbose by their very nature.

These snapshots will in the future help to prevent regressions if someone makes a mistaken change in the OCaml generator as I had done previously.
I wasn't really asking for a fix nor volunteering, just keeping a record of my long and winding path to figuring out how to run the codegen unit tests :-)
@Jens-G do you think this can be merged? the refresh script did run correctly. the main errors are the same with `master`, i.e. Java errors, for which I'm trying to find time to fix.
The build errors seem all unrelated, but I'll pull this first into my local CI and test there, to be sure.
Ok, build errors are unrelated and the changes work in my local CI too, merging. Thanks!
cmake flows failures will be caught by GitHub actions as well so we should rely on that to do fast sanity check
+1 LGTM
hmmm, I only made one change but forked from main.  Closing for now.  Will reopen against main.

[1]: https://app.travis-ci.com/github/apache/thrift/builds/255796476
i wonder what is a better fix, to change all relative paths to absolute one or to just update somewhere once to fix the `docs` prefix?

> i wonder what is a better fix, to change all relative paths to absolute one or to just update somewhere once to fix the `docs` prefix?

This is determined by the location of the static resource (image).

For example:

`https://thrift.apache.org/docs/Languages.html` was under `/docs/`, so that relative assets will load with prefix  `/docs/`

`doc/images/cgrn.png`-> `/docs/doc/images/cgrn.png` ❌

However if we change correct relative path -> `../doc/images/cgrn.png`, this will break github preview. 


Move `doc/images` to `docs/images`, then add the `/docs` prefix to every static resource(image), maybe this is a better fix.

Change all doc will break search result of search engine.

Hi @Jens-G I'm trying to resolve the `opam` error by disabling sandboxing which isn't needed given it's already run within a docker image.

this will expose other failures in swift but it can be fixed in a subsequent PR.

I removed the last element in `thrift_spec` tuples with default instance (it was used only in `__init__` to check the param value, but it was always failing). I don't see any other place where it's still in use.

> @allengeorge per discussion in #2700, @fishy suggested that we do not bring any 3rd dependencies (in go library). here we are facing the same issue, do you believe we shall remove the uuid dependency in rust?

go library is slightly different in that it already has zero third party dependency right now so there's a big incentive to keep it that way, which does not apply to rust library (which I _believe_ already have third party dependencies).
sure as I said that can totally be done in a follow up pr instead.

I could remove the setup from GitHub actions from this PR because the current GitHub runner already includes Swift 5.7 (but that might change in the future which is why I wanted to explicitly standardize it). Then we can resolve the issues with Github actions separately. 

The issue is mainly with Travis which includes a much older version that won't compile the current code

@Jens-G - should be ready

Currently seeing a bunch of MSVC errors like the one below:
```
C:\projects\thrift\lib\cpp\src\thrift/numeric_cast.h(47): warning C4003: not enough arguments for function-like macro invocation 'max' [C:\projects\build\MSVC2017\x64\lib\cpp\thrift.vcxproj]
C:\projects\thrift\lib\cpp\src\thrift/numeric_cast.h(50): warning C4003: not enough arguments for function-like macro invocation 'max' [C:\projects\build\MSVC2017\x64\lib\cpp\thrift.vcxproj]
  ThreadManager.cpp
  TimerManager.cpp
  PeekProcessor.cpp
...
C:\projects\thrift\lib\cpp\src\thrift/numeric_cast.h(47): error C2589: '(': illegal token on right side of '::' 
```

It looks as though MSVC defines `max(a, b)` as a macro everywhere. This is ~questionable for C, but not good for C++ since we have `std::max()` but then also [std::numeric_limits<T>::max()](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/types/numeric_limits/max) and likely others.

> I could remove the setup from GitHub actions from this PR because the current GitHub runner already includes Swift 5.7 (but that might change in the future which is why I wanted to explicitly standardize it). Then we can resolve the issues with Github actions separately.
> 
> The issue is mainly with Travis which includes a much older version that won't compile the current code

i'm okay with this direction.

@emmenlau Do you want to merge this pull request? If I can't get any response or comment for another week, I will close this pull request.

Dear @africamonkey , I'm really sorry but I'm not all too deep in that code and find it slightly difficult to wrap my head around the implementation. Can you explain the logic, either in a comment in the code, or here in the chat?

Basically my questions are:
 - Why was the old implementation incorrect and/or is your new implementation better?
 - Why is the `!=` operator not just calling the `==` operator and returning the negated result?

Hi @emmenlau 

> Why was the old implementation incorrect and/or is your new implementation better?

The old implementation assumes that the right hand side is the end of the iterator. So it's obviously incorrect. Basically, a `!=` operator should have commutative law, which is: `lhs != rhs <=> rhs != lhs`. 

The old one:
```C++
  bool operator!=(const TEnumIterator& end) {
    THRIFT_UNUSED_VARIABLE(end);
    assert(end.n_ == -1);  // assume this is the end iterator
    return (ii_ != n_);  // only check the left hand side because we assumed the right hand side is end iterator
  }
```

I'm writing a new operator which can handle general cases, which can also satisfy the commutative law. 

The new logic is that:
```C++
  bool operator==(const TEnumIterator& rhs) const {
    bool is_end = ii_ == n_ || n_ == -1;  // check if left hand side is an end iterator. 
    bool is_rhs_end = rhs.ii_ == rhs.n_ || rhs.n_ == -1;  // check if right hand side is an end iterator. 
    return (ii_ == rhs.ii_ && n_ == rhs.n_) || (is_end && is_rhs_end);
  }
```
Note that https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/984b59a2b4edb03479947c46007fc6142447f759/cpp/src/generated/parquet_types.cpp#L36 uses `n_ = -1` to represent the end iterator, so we need to regard either `ii_ == n_` or `n_ == -1` as an end iterator. They should be the same. 
Obviously, if `ii_` and `n_` are the same, they should be the same iterators. Otherwise, if they are both end iterator, they should be regarded as the same iterators. 

> Why is the `!=` operator not just calling the `==` operator and returning the negated result?

I pushed a new commit. Now the `!=` operator is just calling the `==` operator.
